data.title: Nobel Laureates from Africa - Edmonton Public Library
data.meta_description:
Nobel Laureates from Africa by Capital_City_Press - a staff-created list : Capital City Press Featured Writer Peter Midgley says of this list:

For four dreadful years, I have felt an overwhelming need to rediscover humanity and compassion. In my search, I returned to a lifetime of individuals who have inspired me. As I worked through my list, I realised how many of them were, or are, Nobel laureates: Africa has produced 28 Nobel laureates in field as diverse as Physics (2), Chemistry (3), Medicine or Physiology (3), Peace (14), and Literature (6). And thus the idea for this list was born: inspiring books by African Nobel laureates.
A few names that do appear on this list may come as a surprise, mostly because their names are generally associated with other parts of the world. They are included here because they were born in Africa and spent at least part of their formative years on the continent.
data.text:
Staff-created list

Capital City Press Featured Writer Peter Midgley says of this list: For four dreadful years, I have felt an overwhelming need to rediscover humanity and compassion. In my search, I returned to a lifetime of individuals who have inspired me. As I worked through my list, I realised how many of them were, or are, Nobel laureates: Africa has produced 28 Nobel laureates in field as diverse as Physics (2), Chemistry (3), Medicine or Physiology (3), Peace (14), and Literature (6). And thus the idea for this list was born: inspiring books by African Nobel laureates. A few names that do appear on this list may come as a surprise, mostly because their names are generally associated with other parts of the world. They are included here because they were born in Africa and spent at least part of their formative years on the continent.

Desmond Tutu’s message of forgiveness did not start with the Truth and Reconciliation Commission in South Africa. As a schoolboy in early 1980s, before De...Show more Desmond Tutu’s message of forgiveness did not start with the Truth and Reconciliation Commission in South Africa. As a schoolboy in early 1980s, before Desmond Tutu was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984, I heard him preach at the Cathedral of St. Andrew and St. Michael in Bloemfontein, South Africa. I’d gone with a group of friends mainly to avoid another Sunday evening in the school hostel; I left the Cathedral forever changed. [Also available as an eAudiobook] Show less

All copies in use. Availability details

It is hard to pick a favourite Camus text, who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1957. L’etranger (The Stranger or The Outsider) is possibly the best-...Show more It is hard to pick a favourite Camus text, who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1957. L’etranger (The Stranger or The Outsider) is possibly the best-known among his books and an obvious one to include on a reading list. But doing so allows us to forget the intense exploration of his commitment to Algeria, the land of his birth, in Algerian Chronicles, and to overlook his significant ability as a short story writer in Exile and the Kingdom. [Also available as an eAudiobook and eBook] Show less

All copies in use. Availability details Holds: 6 on 6 copies

I read a contraband copy of Mandela’s 1965 book, No Easy Walk to Freedom, as a student in the 1980s. I followed it up with a heavily redacted copy of Fati...Show more I read a contraband copy of Mandela’s 1965 book, No Easy Walk to Freedom, as a student in the 1980s. I followed it up with a heavily redacted copy of Fatima Meer’s biography, Higher than Hope (published in 1988 by Skotaville Publishers—two years before the international version appeared). Both Long Walk to Freedom and Conversations with Myself continue the conversation started in No Easy Walk, offering words of hope and inspiration insights from one of the most the world’s most iconic figures. Nelson Mandela won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1993. [Also available as a book, audiobook, and eAudiobook] Show less

Wole Soyinka of Nigeria won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1986. Soyinka’s relentless pursuit of democracy and human rights as an adult started in his ...Show more Wole Soyinka of Nigeria won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1986. Soyinka’s relentless pursuit of democracy and human rights as an adult started in his childhood. You Must Set Forth at Dawn is a lyrical account of Soyinka’s early years, and an exploration of an awakening political consciousness. Show less

As the second African to hold the position of Secretary-General of the United Nations (following Boutros Boutros-Ghali), Kofi Annan’s tenure included tryi...Show more As the second African to hold the position of Secretary-General of the United Nations (following Boutros Boutros-Ghali), Kofi Annan’s tenure included trying to orchestrate a global response to the Rwanda genocide and. His heartfelt account of the UN’s successes (a global effort to combat HIV) and failures (Rwanda) is a testament to the difficulties that beset international co-operation, while also highlighting its importance, especially now. This remains a book for our times as we find ourselves in the middle of a global pandemic. Annan won the Nobel Peace Prize in 2001. Show less

The three books of Naguib Mahfouz’s Cairo Trilogy make haunting reading. Nadine Gordimer, another African Nobel laureate, writes in Writing and Being how ...Show more The three books of Naguib Mahfouz’s Cairo Trilogy make haunting reading. Nadine Gordimer, another African Nobel laureate, writes in Writing and Being how Mahfouz and Chinua Achebe present another world, one in which “the postcolonial world … bears on the face of ancient Egypt and old Africa the paint and patches of foreign occupations.” There is little more to say. There is much more to say. Mahfouz (Nobel Prize for Literature, 1988) completes the trilogy with Palace of Desire and Sugar Street. [Also available in print and eAudiobook] Show less

The urgency of addressing climate change increases daily, and Wangari Maathai’s prescient grassroots activism with the Green Belt Movement is just one par...Show more The urgency of addressing climate change increases daily, and Wangari Maathai’s prescient grassroots activism with the Green Belt Movement is just one part of the wisdom she draws upon in her quest to find ways for humans to heal themselves, and the earth. Maathai won the Nobel Peace Prize in 2004. Show less

Burger’s Daughter is, by any standard, a tour de force. Gordimer (Nobel Prize for Literature, 1991) takes us into the heart of the Soweto protests in 1976...Show more Burger’s Daughter is, by any standard, a tour de force. Gordimer (Nobel Prize for Literature, 1991) takes us into the heart of the Soweto protests in 1976, a moment that sparked a renewed sense of anti-apartheid activism. Commitment and complicity are laid bare as two sides of what we now call “white allyship”. [Also available as a book] Show less

Leymah Gbowee’s resilience in the face of unspeakable abuse and wartime violence underscores why women, who are disproportionately affected by war, should...Show more Leymah Gbowee’s resilience in the face of unspeakable abuse and wartime violence underscores why women, who are disproportionately affected by war, should be central to peacebuilding. Gbowee’s book needs to be read in conjunction with Ellen Sirleaf Johnson’s biography (This Child Will Be Great), with whom she shared the Peace Prize in 2011. Where Gbowee offers insights from the perspective of a grassroots activist, Sirleaf Johnson provides an account of the same struggle from the perspective of a career politician. [Also available as an eAudiobook] Show less

Coetzee won the Nobel Prize for Disgrace in 2003, a disturbing book that should now be read in conjunction with Fiona Synckers’ award-winning book, Lacuna...Show more Coetzee won the Nobel Prize for Disgrace in 2003, a disturbing book that should now be read in conjunction with Fiona Synckers’ award-winning book, Lacuna, in which Snyckers writes back to Disgrace, questioning the narrative from a feminist perspective. Also by Coetzee, Life and Times of Michael K is a devastating book. The gradual descent into threadbare existence is terrifying. Rarely has such an apocalyptic vision haunted fiction. To contrast that, read Nthikeng Mohlele’s Michael K, in which Mohlele unpacks the disconnected world of Michael K from the perspective of a black writer. Between them, Mohlele and Snyckers render powerful critiques of the literary establishment. [Also available in print] Show less
